Now again he sucks this child’s wound—how can I know where he will die?
Mei Yaochen says: Nurture them with care, and they will remain close and never leave; love them and urge them on, and they will trust without doubt. Thus, though death comes, they die with you; though peril comes, they face it with you.
Wang Xi says: This is to bind men’s hearts with kindness and grace.
He Shi says: As in later Han, when Duan Jiong served as General Who Breaks the Qiang. On campaign against the Western Qiang, he showed deep care for his soldiers, personally visiting the wounded and binding their wounds with his own hands. For over a decade on the frontier, he never once slept on a mat, sharing hardship with his officers and men—thus all were glad to fight to the death for him. When Jin’s Wang Jun was governor of Ba Commandery, which bordered Wu, the soldiers suffered under heavy labor, and many newborn sons were abandoned. Wang Jun then tightened regulations but lightened corvée duties, granting those who bore children exemption and rest. Thousands of lives were thus preserved. Later, when he launched his campaign against Wu, those saved in Ba Commandery were all fit for military service. Their parents exhorted them: “Lord Wang gave you life—you must strive for him and not shrink from death.” Thus Wu’s forces faced an army of fathers and sons.
Zhang Yu says: If a general treats his soldiers as sons, they will regard him as a father. Never has a father faced danger without his sons rushing to die for him. Thus Xun Qing said: “A minister’s service to his lord, a subordinate’s to his superior, is like a younger brother’s to an elder, like hands and feet protecting the head and eyes.” Fine wine flows freely, and the whole army grows drunk; a single warm word, and the soldiers feel as if wrapped in silk. Truly, the way one treats subordinates with grace was prized by the ancients. Thus the *Art of War* says: When the army toils, the general must go first—he does not raise an umbrella in the heat, nor wear layered robes in the cold; on perilous paths, he dismounts and walks. He drinks only after the army’s well is dug, eats only after the army’s food is cooked, rests only after the army’s camp is built. If you are generous but cannot command, loving but cannot order, disorderly but cannot govern, they are like spoiled children—useless.
Cao Cao says: Grace alone cannot be relied upon, nor punishment alone. Like a spoiled child’s whims, they will turn to harm and prove useless.
Li Quan says: Though you love them deeply, if they become like spoiled children with rebellious hearts, they cannot be used.
Du Mu says: The *Three Strategies of Huang Shigong* states: “Soldiers may be humbled but must not be spoiled.” Grace nurtures them, humility treats them well—hence “may be humbled.” Law restrains them—hence “must not be spoiled.” The *Yinfu Jing* says: “Harm arises from grace.” Wu Qi said: “Drums, gongs, and bells strike awe into the ears; banners and insignia strike awe into the eyes; prohibitions and punishments strike awe into the heart. Ears awed by sound cannot but be sharp; eyes awed by sight cannot but be clear; hearts awed by punishment cannot but be stern. If these three are not established, defeat by the enemy is certain.” Thus, when a general raises his hand, none fail to follow; where he points, none fail to advance to their deaths.
Li Jing, Duke of Wei, said: The finest generals of old could execute three out of ten soldiers, and the next best one out of ten. Executing three out of ten strikes terror into enemy nations; executing one out of ten ensures orders are obeyed throughout the army. Those who fear me do not fear the enemy; those who fear the enemy do not fear me. Reward every good deed, no matter how small; punish every fault, no matter how minor. When Ma Su’s army was defeated, Zhuge Liang wept as he carried out the execution. When a villager stole a bamboo hat, Lü Meng shed tears before beheading him. When a horse trampled crops, Cao Cao cut his own hair as punishment. When two officials were found guilty, Huang Gai interrogated and executed them both. Thus, when awe overcomes love, even a small force will prevail; when love overcomes awe, even a large force will fail.
Meng Shi says: If you focus only on grace, once the power of grace is established, punishment will breed resentment. If you focus only on punishment, once resentment runs deep, grace will not win them over. You must blend grace and awe, reward and punishment—only then can you be a general, only then can you lead the masses.
Mei Yaochen says: If you nurture them generously but cannot command, dote on them but do not teach them, allow disorder but do not govern them, they are like spoiled children—how can they be of use?
Wang Xi says: Grace without strictness cannot succeed.
He Shi says: Grace cannot be used alone; used alone, it will turn to harm.
Zhang Yu says: Grace cannot be used exclusively, nor punishment alone. If you rely solely on grace, soldiers become like spoiled children and cannot be commanded. This is why Cao Cao cut his own hair as punishment, why Zhuge Liang wept as he carried out executions, why Yang Su’s blood flowed before him yet he laughed as if nothing had happened, why Li Jing executed three out of ten to ensure his men feared him more than the enemy. If you rely solely on punishment, soldiers will not draw close and cannot be used. This is why ancient generals would pour out wine, why the Lord of Chu wrapped his men in silk, why Wu Qi shared his clothes and food, why Helü shared their labor and rest. In the *Book of Changes*, the *Initial Six* of the *Army* hexagram says, “The army marches by law,” meaning to unite the masses through discipline. The *Nine in the Second* says, “The army receives Heaven’s favor,” meaning to encourage soldiers with rewards. From this we see that the armies of true kings balance virtue and punishment, grace and awe.
The *Weiliaozi* says: “If you do not please their hearts, they will not serve you; if you do not strike awe into their hearts, they will not rise for you.” Thus, the good general relies on both love and awe.

If you know the enemy can be struck but do not know your troops are unfit to strike, your chance of victory is half. Du Mu says: “Can be struck” means they are brave and scorn death.

chunks.original_text: 不可击者，顿弊怯弱也。 陈皞曰：此说非也。 可击不可击者，所谓兵众孰强，士卒孰练，赏罚孰明也。 梅尧臣曰：知彼而不知己，或有胜耳。 王晳曰：知己不知彼，知彼不知己，皆未可以决胜也。 张预曰：或知己而不知彼，或知彼而不知己，则有胜有负也。 唐太宗曰：吾尝临陈，先料敌心与己之心孰审，然后彼可得而知焉； 察敌气与己之气孰治，然后我可得而知焉。 言料心审治乱，察气见强弱形也，可战与不可战也。 知敌之可击，知吾卒之可以击，而不知地形之不可以战，胜之半也。 曹操、李筌曰：胜之半者，未可知也。 杜牧曰：地形者，险易、远近、出入、迂直也。 梅尧臣曰：知彼知己，而不知地形，亦或不胜。 王晳曰：虽知彼己可以战，然不可亏地利也。 张预曰：既知己，而又知彼，但不得地形之助，亦不可全胜。 故知兵者，动而不迷，举而不穷。 杜牧曰：未动未举，胜负已定，故动则不迷，举则不穷也。 一云动而不困，举而不顿。 陈皞曰：穷者，困也。 我若识彼此之动否，量地形之得失，则进而不迷，战而不困者也。 梅尧臣曰：无所不知，则动不迷暗，举不困穷也。 王晳曰：善计者不迷，善军者不穷。 张预曰：不妄动，故动则不误； 不轻举，故举则不困。 识彼我之虚实，得地形之便利，而后战也。 故曰：知彼知己，胜乃不殆； 张预曰：晓攻守之术，则有胜而无危。 知天知地，胜乃不穷。 李筌曰：人事、天时、地利三者同知，则百战百胜。 杜佑曰：知地之便，知天之时。 地之便，依险阻、向高阳也； 天之时，顺寒暑、法刑德也。 既能知彼知己，又按地形法天道，胜乃可全，又何难也。 梅尧臣曰：知彼利，知此利，故不危； 知天时、知地形、故不极。 王晳同梅尧臣注。 张预曰：顺天时，得地利，取胜无极。 孙子注解卷之十竟 #1『道』原作『通』，据郭化若校改。 孙子注解卷之十一 九地篇

Those unfit to strike are weary, exhausted, timid, or weak. Chen Hao says: This explanation is incorrect. Whether an enemy can or cannot be struck depends on which army is stronger in numbers, which troops are better trained, and which side enforces rewards and punishments more clearly. Mei Yaochen says: Knowing the enemy but not yourself may still bring victory. Wang Xi says: Knowing yourself but not the enemy, or knowing the enemy but not yourself, neither guarantees victory. Zhang Yu says: Some know themselves but not the enemy; some know the enemy but not themselves—thus, victory or defeat may follow.

Emperor Taizong of Tang says: When I once faced the enemy in battle, I first assessed whether the enemy’s mind or my own was more discerning, and only then could I truly know them. I examined whether the enemy’s *qi* or my own was more ordered, and only then could I truly know myself. This means weighing the clarity of intentions and the order of *qi* to discern strength and weakness—whether to engage or not.

If you know the enemy can be struck and your troops are fit to strike, but do not know the terrain is unfit for battle, your chance of victory is half. Cao Cao and Li Quan say: A fifty-percent chance of victory is still uncertain. Du Mu says: Terrain refers to its hazards or ease, distance or proximity, entry and exit points, and whether it is circuitous or direct. Mei Yaochen says: Knowing the enemy and yourself but not the terrain may still lead to defeat. Wang Xi says: Even if you know both enemy and self are fit for battle, you must not forfeit the advantage of terrain. Zhang Yu says: Though you know yourself and the enemy, without the aid of terrain, you cannot secure complete victory.

Thus, one who truly knows warfare moves without confusion and acts without exhaustion. Du Mu says: Before moving or acting, victory or defeat is already decided—hence, movement is never confused, and action is never exhausted. Another version reads: moves without entanglement and acts without weariness. Chen Hao says: *Exhaustion* here means entanglement. If I understand the enemy’s movements and my own, and assess the gains and losses of terrain, then advancing brings no confusion, and battle brings no entanglement. Mei Yaochen says: Knowing all, one moves without blindness and acts without exhaustion. Wang Xi says: One skilled in strategy is never confused; one skilled in warfare is never exhausted. Zhang Yu says: Not moving recklessly ensures no mistakes; not acting lightly ensures no entanglement. Only after discerning the enemy’s and one’s own strengths and weaknesses, and securing the advantages of terrain, should one fight.

Thus it is said: Know the enemy and know yourself, and victory will not be imperiled. Zhang Yu says: Mastering the arts of attack and defense ensures victory without danger. Know Heaven and know Earth, and victory will know no bounds. Li Quan says: When human affairs, Heaven’s timing, and Earth’s advantages are all understood, every battle is won. Du You says: Know the advantages of terrain and the seasons of Heaven. Terrain’s advantages lie in relying on hazards, facing high and sunny ground; Heaven’s seasons lie in following cold and heat, and aligning with punitive and virtuous *qi*. If you know both enemy and self, and further align with terrain and the Dao of Heaven, victory can be complete—what difficulty remains? Mei Yaochen says: Knowing the enemy’s advantage and your own ensures no peril; knowing Heaven’s timing and Earth’s terrain ensures no limit. Wang Xi’s note agrees with Mei Yaochen. Zhang Yu says: Following Heaven’s timing and securing Earth’s advantages, victory has no end.

*Commentary on Sunzi, Scroll Ten ends*
*Commentary on Sunzi, Scroll Eleven: "Nine Terrains"*

chunks.original_text: 曹操曰：欲战之地有九。 李筌曰：胜敌之地有九，故决地形之下。 王晳曰：用兵之地，利害有九也。 张预曰：用兵之地，其势有九。 此论地势，故次地形。 孙子曰：用兵之法，有散地，有轻地，有争地，有交地，有衢地，有重地，有圮地，有围地，有死地。 曹操曰：此九地之名也。 张预曰：此九地之名。 诸侯自战其地，为散地。 曹操曰：士卒恋土，道近易散。 李筌曰：卒恃土，怀妻子，急则散，是为散地也。 杜牧曰：士卒近家，进无必死之心，退有归投之处。 杜佑曰：战其境内之地，士卒意不专，有溃散之心，故曰散地。 梅尧臣同杜牧注。 王晳同曹操注。 何氏曰：散地，士卒恃之，怀恋妻子，急则散走，是为散地。 一曰地无关键，士卒易散走，居此地者，不可数战。 又曰地远四平，更无要害，志意不坚而易离，故曰散地。 吴王问孙武曰：散地，士卒顾家，不可与战，则必固守不出。 若敌攻我小城，掠吾田野，禁吾樵采，塞吾要道，待吾空虚而急来攻则如之何？ 武曰：敌人深入吾都，多背城邑士卒以军为家，专志轻斗； 吾兵在国，安土怀生，以陈则不坚，以斗则不胜。 当集人各众，聚谷蓄帛，保城备险遣轻兵绝其粮道； 彼挑战不得，转输不至，野无所掠，三军困馁，因而诱之，可以有功。 若欲野战，则必因势依险设伏，无险则隐於天气阴晦昏雾其懈怠，出其不意，袭其懈怠，可以有功。 张预曰：战於境内，士卒顾家，是易散之地也。 郧人将伐楚师，楚斗廉曰：郑人军其郊，必不诫； 恃近其城，莫有斗志。 果为楚所败是也。 入人之地而不深者，为轻地。 曹操曰：士卒皆轻返也。 杜牧曰：师出越境，必焚舟梁，示民无返顾之心。 李筌曰：轻於退也。 梅尧臣曰：入敌未远，道近轻返。 王晳曰：初涉敌境势轻，士未有斗志也。 何氏曰：轻地者，轻於退也。 入敌境未深，往返轻易不可止息，将不得数动劳人。 吴王问孙武曰：吾至轻地，始入敌境，士卒思还，难进易退； 未背险阻，三军恐惧； 大将欲进，士卒欲退，上下异心。 敌守其城垒，整其车骑，或当吾前，或击吾后，则如之何？ 武曰：军至轻地，士卒未专，以入为务，无以战为。 故无近其名城，无由其通路，设疑佯惑，示若将去； 选骁骑，衔枚先入，掠其牛马六畜。 三军见得，进乃不惧。 分吾良卒，密有所伏，敌人若来，击之勿疑； 若其不至，舍之而去。 又曰：军入敌境，敌人固垒不战，士卒思归，欲退且难，谓之轻地。 当选骁兵伏要路，我退敌追，来则击之也。 张预曰：始入敌境，士卒思还，是轻返之地也。 尉缭子曰：征役分军而归，或临战自北，则逃伤甚焉。 言民兵四集，分屯占地，使北来者当北道，则多逃，以其开之耳。 我得则利，彼得亦利者，为争地。 曹操曰：可以少胜众，弱击强。 李筌曰：此阨喉守险地，先居者胜，是为争地也。 杜牧曰：必争之地，乃险要也。 前秦符坚先遣大将吕光讨西域，坚败绩后，光自西域还，师至宜禾，坚凉州刺史梁熙谋拒之。 高昌太守杨翰曰：吕光新定西国，兵强气锐，其锋不可当。 若出流沙，其势难测。 高梧谷口险要，宜先守之，而夺其水；

Cao Cao says: There are nine types of terrain for battle.
Li Quan says: There are nine terrains where victory over the enemy may be decided, hence the discussion follows "Terrain."
Wang Xi says: In the terrains where armies operate, advantages and disadvantages number nine.
Zhang Yu says: In the terrains where armies operate, their strategic conditions number nine. This discusses terrain’s strategic conditions, hence it follows "Terrain."

Sunzi says: In the methods of using armies, there is *dispersive terrain*, *light terrain*, *contentious terrain*, *intersecting terrain*, *thoroughfare terrain*, *heavy terrain*, *impassable terrain*, *encircled terrain*, and *death terrain*.

Cao Cao says: These are the names of the nine terrains.
Zhang Yu says: These are the names of the nine terrains.

When feudal lords fight on their own land, it is *dispersive terrain*.
Cao Cao says: Soldiers cling to their homeland; the proximity makes them easily scattered.
Li Quan says: Soldiers rely on their native soil, cherish their wives and children, and scatter when pressed—this is *dispersive terrain*.
Du Mu says: Soldiers are near their homes; they lack the resolve to fight to the death and have places to flee.
Du You says: Fighting on one’s own territory, soldiers’ minds are not single-minded; they harbor thoughts of breaking and scattering—hence it is called *dispersive terrain*.
Mei Yaochen concurs with Du Mu’s note.
Wang Xi concurs with Cao Cao’s note.
He [Yan]shi says: In *dispersive terrain*, soldiers rely on it, cherish their wives and children, and scatter when pressed—this is *dispersive terrain*. One says: terrain without strategic passes, where soldiers easily scatter; those stationed here cannot fight repeatedly. Another says: terrain far and level on all sides, without critical strongholds, where resolve is weak and easily broken—hence it is called *dispersive terrain*.

King of Wu asked Sun Wu: In *dispersive terrain*, soldiers think of home and cannot be made to fight; thus, one must firmly defend and not sally forth. If the enemy attacks our small cities, plunders our fields, cuts off our firewood-gathering, blocks our vital roads, and waits until we are depleted before launching a swift attack—what should be done?
Sun Wu replied: If the enemy deeply penetrates our capital, they will have many soldiers with their backs to cities, treating the army as home, and will fight with single-minded ferocity. Our troops, being in our own land, are attached to the soil and cling to life; in formation, they are not steadfast, and in battle, they do not prevail. One should gather the people in great numbers, amass grain and silk, defend cities and secure strategic points, and send light troops to sever their supply lines. If they challenge for battle and receive no response, and their provisions fail to arrive, with nothing to plunder in the wilds, the three armies will be distressed and starving. Seizing this opportunity to lure them will yield success. If one wishes to fight in the open, one must rely on the terrain, set ambushes in strategic points, or, lacking such points, conceal oneself in overcast, dark, or foggy weather to exploit their laxity. Striking unexpectedly and ambushing their negligence can yield success.

Zhang Yu says: Fighting within one’s borders, soldiers think of home—this is terrain where they are easily scattered. When the people of Yun intended to attack the Chu army, Chu’s Dou Lian said: "The Zheng army is camped in their outskirts and will surely not be on guard; relying on the proximity of their city, they will lack fighting spirit." Indeed, they were defeated by Chu—this is an example.

When entering another’s land but not deeply, it is *light terrain*.
Cao Cao says: Soldiers all lightly return.
Du Mu says: When the army crosses the border, one must burn boats and bridges to show the people there is no thought of retreat.
Li Quan says: They are light in retreating.
Mei Yaochen says: Entering the enemy’s land but not far, the way back is short and retreat is easy.
Wang Xi says: Initially entering enemy territory, the situation is light, and soldiers lack fighting spirit.
He [Yan]shi says: *Light terrain* is terrain where retreat is easy. Entering enemy territory but not deeply, going and returning are easy, and one cannot halt or rest; the general must not repeatedly exhaust the people.

King of Wu asked Sun Wu: When I reach *light terrain*, having just entered enemy territory, soldiers long to return, advancing is difficult and retreating easy; without the protection of strategic hazards, the three armies are fearful. The commander wishes to advance, but the soldiers wish to retreat—superiors and subordinates are at odds. If the enemy defends their fortifications, arrays their chariots and cavalry, and either blocks our front or strikes our rear—what should be done?
Sun Wu replied: When the army reaches *light terrain*, soldiers are not yet single-minded; entering is their priority, not fighting. Thus, do not approach their famous cities or pass through their thoroughfares. Set up deceptive and confusing displays, feigning departure. Select elite cavalry, have them hold bits in their mouths, and enter first to seize their cattle, horses, and livestock. When the three armies see gains, they will no longer fear advancing. Divide our elite troops and secretly set ambushes; if the enemy comes, strike without hesitation. If they do not come, leave and depart.

Another says: When the army enters enemy territory and the enemy fortifies their ramparts without fighting, soldiers long to return, and retreat is difficult—this is *light terrain*. One should select elite soldiers to ambush key roads; if we retreat and the enemy pursues, strike when they come.

Zhang Yu says: Initially entering enemy territory, soldiers long to return—this is terrain where retreat is easy. The *Wei Liaozi* says: When conscripted troops are divided and return, or face battle and flee north, the losses are severe. This means that when civilian soldiers are assembled from all directions and divided into encampments occupying land, those coming from the north are assigned to the northern route, and many flee because the way is open.

Where what we gain is advantageous and what the enemy gains is also advantageous, it is *contentious terrain*.
Cao Cao says: Where the few can defeat the many, the weak can strike the strong.
Li Quan says: This is terrain guarding strategic choke points; the first to occupy it wins—hence it is *contentious terrain*.
Du Mu says: Terrain that must be contested is strategically critical. Former Qin’s Fu Jian first sent his general Lü Guang to subdue the Western Regions. After Fu Jian’s defeat, Lü Guang returned from the Western Regions. When his army reached Yihe, Fu Jian’s Liangzhou Prefect Liang Xi plotted to resist him. Yang Han, the Governor of Gaochang, said: "Lü Guang has just pacified the Western Regions; his troops are strong and their morale is high—their advance cannot be withstood. If they emerge from the Flowing Sands, their intentions will be hard to gauge. The Gaowu Gorge is a strategic point; we should first defend it and cut off their water supply..."
chunks.overlap_context:
ou know both enemy and self, and further align with terrain and the Dao of Heaven, victory can be complete—what difficulty remains? Mei Yaochen says: Knowing the enemy’s advantage and your own ensures no peril; knowing Heaven’s timing and Earth’s terrain ensures no limit. Wang Xi’s note agrees with Mei Yaochen. Zhang Yu says: Following Heaven’s timing and securing Earth’s advantages, victory has no end.

*Commentary on Sunzi, Scroll Ten ends*

chunks.original_text: 彼既困渴#1，人自然投戈。 如以为远不可守，伊吾之关，亦可拒之。 若废此二要，难为计矣。 地有所必争，真此机也。 熙不从，竟为光所灭也。 陈皞曰：彼我若先得其地者，则可以少胜众，弱胜强也。 杜佑曰：谓山水阨口，有险固之利，两敌所争。 梅尧臣曰：无我无彼，先得则利。 王晳同陈皞注。 何氏曰：争地，便利之地，先居者胜，是以争之。 吴王问孙武曰：敌若先至，据要保利，简兵练卒，或出或守，以备我奇，则如之何？ 武曰：争地之法，先据为利，敌得其处，慎勿攻之。 引而佯走，建旗呜鼓，趣其所爱，曳柴扬尘，惑其耳目； 分吾良卒，密有所伏，敌必出救。 人欲我与，人弃我取，此争先之道也。 若我先至而敌用此术，则选吾锐卒，固守其所，轻兵追之，分伏险阻，敌人还斗，伏兵旁起，此全胜之道。 张预曰：险固之利，彼我得之，皆可以少胜众，弱胜强者，是必争之地也。 唐太宗以三千人守成皋之险，坐困窦建德十万之众是也。 我可以往，彼可以来者，为交地。 曹操曰：道正相交错也。 杜牧曰：川广地平，可来可往，足以交战对垒。 陈皞曰：交错是也。 言其道路交横，彼我可以来往。 如此之地，则须兵士首尾不绝，切宜备之。 故下文云：交地吾将谨其守。 其义可见也。 杜佑曰：交地有数道往来，交相无可绝。 梅尧臣同陈皞注。 何氏曰：交地，平原交通也。 一曰：可以交结，不可杜绝之，绝之致隙。 又曰：交通四远，不可遏绝。 吴王问孙武曰：交地，吾将绝敌，使不得来。 必令吾边城修其守备，深绝通路，固其隘塞。 若不先图之，敌人已备，彼可得而来，吾不得而往，众寡又均，则如之何？ 武曰：既我不可以往，彼可以来，吾分卒匿之，守而易怠，示其不能。 敌人且至，设伏隐庐，出其不意，可以有功也。 张预曰：地有数道，往来通达，而不可阻绝者，是交错之地也。 诸侯之地三属， 曹操曰：我与敌相当，而旁有他国也。 孟氏曰：若郑界於齐、楚、晋是也。 先至而得天下之众者，为衢地。 曹操曰：先至得其国助也。 李筌曰：对敌之傍，有一国为之属，先往而通之，得其众也。 杜牧曰：衢地者，三属之地，我须先至其冲，据其形势，结其旁国也。 天下，犹言诸侯也。 梅尧臣曰：彼我相当，有旁国三面之会，先至则得诸侯之助也。 王晳曰：曹公云：先至得其国助。 晳谓先至者，结交先至也。 言天下 先之者，谓能广助则天下可从。 何氏曰：衢地者，地要冲，控带数道，先据此地，众必从之，故得之则安，失之则危也。 吴王问孙武曰：衢地必先，若吾道远发后，虽驰车骤马，至不能先，则如之何？ 武曰：诸侯参属，其道四通，我与敌相当，而旁有他国。 所谓先者，必先重币轻使，约和旁国，交亲结恩，兵虽后至，众已属矣。 我有众助，彼失其党，诸国椅角，震鼓齐攻，敌人惊恐，莫知所当。 张预曰：衢者，四通之地。 我所敌者，当其一面，而旁有邻国，三面相连属，当往结之，以为己援。 先至者，谓先遣使以重币约和旁国也。 兵虽后至，已得其国助矣。 入人之地深，背城邑多者，为重地。 曹操曰：难返之地。 李筌曰：坚志也。 白起攻楚，乐毅伐齐皆为重地。 杜牧曰：入人之境已深，过人之城已多，津梁皆为所恃，要冲皆为所据，还师返旆，不可得也。
chunks.translated_text:
When the enemy is thus trapped and parched with thirst, their troops will naturally cast down their weapons. If one deems the Gaowu Gorge too distant to hold, the Yiwu Pass may also serve to block them. Should both these critical points be abandoned, no strategy will avail. There are places one must contest—this is precisely such an opportunity. Liang Xi refused to heed this counsel and was ultimately destroyed by Lü Guang.

Chen Hao says: If either side first secures such terrain, it may use the few to defeat the many, the weak to overcome the strong.
Du You says: This refers to mountain passes or river choke points, where the advantages of natural barriers make them contested by both sides.
Mei Yaochen says: Neither side holds it first—whoever seizes it gains the advantage.
Wang Xi concurs with Chen Hao’s annotation.
He Shi says: *Contentious terrain* is strategically advantageous ground; the first to occupy it prevails, hence it is contested.

King Helü of Wu asked Sun Wu: “If the enemy arrives first, occupies key positions, fortifies their defenses, trains their troops, and deploys flexibly—sometimes advancing, sometimes holding—while preparing to counter my surprise maneuvers, what should I do?”
Sun Wu replied: “The principle of *contentious terrain* is that the first to secure it gains the advantage. If the enemy has already taken such a position, do not attack it. Instead, feign retreat, raise banners, beat drums, and rush toward what they cherish, dragging branches to raise dust and confuse their senses. Meanwhile, conceal elite troops in ambush. The enemy will surely sally forth to rescue their interests. Where others desire, I advance; where others abandon, I seize—this is the way to contest the initiative. If I arrive first and the enemy employs this tactic, select my finest troops to hold the position firmly, send light forces to pursue them, and conceal ambushes in treacherous terrain. When the enemy turns to fight, the ambush will strike from the flanks—this is the way to complete victory.”

Zhang Yu says: Where natural barriers offer strategic advantage, whichever side secures them—whether us or the enemy—can use the few to defeat the many, the weak to overcome the strong. Such is the terrain that must be contested. Emperor Taizong of Tang, with three thousand men guarding the strategic pass at Chenggao, immobilized the hundred thousand troops of Dou Jiande—this is such a case.

Where I may advance and the enemy may approach is called *intersecting terrain*.
Cao Cao says: The roads intersect directly.
Du Mu says: Broad plains and level ground allow free movement for both sides, facilitating direct confrontation.
Chen Hao says: *Intersecting* means the roads crisscross, enabling both sides to come and go. In such terrain, troops must maintain unbroken formations, and vigilance is essential. Hence the following text states: “In *intersecting terrain*, I will carefully guard my positions”—its meaning is evident.
Du You says: *Intersecting terrain* has multiple routes, allowing free passage that cannot be severed.
Mei Yaochen concurs with Chen Hao’s annotation.
He Shi says: *Intersecting terrain* refers to open plains with interconnected roads. Alternatively, it may mean terrain where alliances can be forged but not severed, for severing them breeds enmity. It is also described as land where routes extend in all directions, making blockades impossible.

King Helü of Wu asked Sun Wu: “In *intersecting terrain*, if I wish to cut off the enemy’s approach, I must order my border cities to fortify their defenses, sever communication routes, and secure the passes. But if I fail to plan ahead and the enemy is already prepared, they may come while I cannot advance, our forces are evenly matched—what then?”
Sun Wu replied: “If I cannot advance but the enemy can approach, I will divide my troops and conceal them, appearing lax in defense to lull them into complacency. When the enemy nears, set ambushes in hidden shelters and strike unexpectedly—this can yield success.”

Zhang Yu says: Terrain with multiple routes, allowing free passage that cannot be blocked, is *intersecting terrain*.

Where the lands of several feudal lords converge, the first to arrive and win the allegiance of the realm is said to hold *thoroughfare terrain*.
Cao Cao says: The first to arrive gains the support of the state.
Li Quan says: Beside the enemy lies a neighboring state; the first to establish communication with it wins its allegiance.
Du Mu says: *Thoroughfare terrain* is where three states converge. I must arrive first at the strategic junction, control its topography, and forge alliances with the neighboring states. “The realm” here refers to the feudal lords.
Mei Yaochen says: Where my forces and the enemy’s face each other, and a neighboring state lies at the convergence of three fronts, the first to arrive gains the support of the feudal lords.
Wang Xi says: Cao Cao states that the first to arrive gains the state’s support. I interpret “first to arrive” as establishing diplomatic ties first. “Winning the realm” means securing broad support, thereby uniting the feudal lords.
He Shi says: *Thoroughfare terrain* is a strategic hub controlling multiple routes. The first to occupy it will win the allegiance of the masses—hence securing it brings stability, while losing it invites peril.

King Helü of Wu asked Sun Wu: “In *thoroughfare terrain*, the first to act gains the advantage. But if my forces are distant and set out later, even with swift chariots and galloping horses, I cannot arrive first—what then?”
Sun Wu replied: “Where the lands of several feudal lords converge, with routes extending in all directions, my forces and the enemy’s face each other, and a neighboring state lies nearby. The so-called ‘first’ refers to dispatching envoys with generous gifts and humble demeanor to negotiate alliances with the neighboring states, fostering friendship and goodwill. Even if my troops arrive later, the people’s allegiance will already be secured. With their support, the enemy loses their allies. The neighboring states will coordinate their efforts, drums will thunder in unison, and the enemy, struck with terror, will not know where to turn.”

Zhang Yu says: *Thoroughfare* refers to land with routes extending in all directions. My enemy faces me on one side, while neighboring states lie on the other three, all connected. I must go and forge alliances with them as my support. “First to arrive” means dispatching envoys with generous gifts to negotiate alliances with the neighboring states. Even if my troops arrive later, I will have already secured their support.

Where one penetrates deeply into enemy territory, leaving many cities and towns behind, it is called *heavy terrain*.
Cao Cao says: Land from which return is difficult.
Li Quan says: Terrain requiring unwavering resolve. Bai Qi’s campaign against Chu and Yue Yi’s conquest of Qi were both *heavy terrain*.
Du Mu says: Having advanced deep into enemy territory and passed many cities, with river crossings and key routes already under their control, retreat becomes impossible.

If they emerge from the Flowing Sands, their intentions will be hard to gauge. The Gaowu Gorge is a strategic point; we should first defend it and cut off their water supply..."

chunks.original_text: 杜佑曰：难返还也。 背，去也； 背与倍同。 多，道里也。 远去己城郭，深入敌地，心专意一，谓之重地也。 梅尧臣曰：乘虚而入，涉地愈深，过城已多，津要绝塞，故曰重难之地。 王晳曰：兵至此者，事势重也。 何氏曰：重地者，入敌已深，国粮难应资给，将士不掠何取？ 吴王问孙武曰：吾引兵深入重地，多所踰越，粮道绝塞，设欲归还，势不可过，欲食於敌，持兵不失，则如之何？ 武曰：凡居重地，士卒轻勇，转输不通，则掠以继食，下得粟帛，皆贡於上，多者有赏，士卒无归意。 若欲还出，即为戒备，深沟高垒，示敌且久。 敌疑通途，私除要害之道，乃令轻车衔枚而行，以牛马为饵。 敌人若出，鸣鼓随之，阴伏吾士，与之中期，内外相应，其败可知也。 张预曰：深涉敌境，多过敌城，士卒心专，无有归志，是难退之地也。 司马景王谓诸葛恪卷甲深入，其锋不可当是也。 行山林、险阻、沮泽，凡难行之道者，为圯地。 曹操曰：少固也。 贾林曰：经水所毁曰圯。 沮洳圯地，不得久留，宜速去也。 梅尧臣曰：水所毁圯，行则犹难，况战守乎？ 何氏曰：圯地者，少固之地也，不可为城垒沟隍，宜速去之。 吴王问孙武曰：吾入圯地，山川险阻，难从之道，行久卒劳； 敌在吾前，而伏吾后，营在吾左，而守吾右； 良车骁骑，要吾隘道，则如之何？ 武曰：先进轻车，去军十里，与敌相候，接期险阻； 或分而左，或分而右，大将四观，择空而取，皆会中道，倦而乃止。 张预曰：险阻渐洳之地，进退艰难，而无所依。 所由入者隘，所从归者迂，彼寡可以击吾之众者，为围地。 李筌曰：举动难也。 杜牧曰：出入艰难，易设奇伏覆胜也。 杜佑曰：所从入阨险，归道远也，持久则粮乏，故敌可以少击吾众者，为围地也。 梅尧臣曰：山川围绕，入则隘，归则迂也。 何氏曰：围地入则隘险，归则迂回，进退无从，虽众何用？ 能为奇变，此地可由。 吴王问孙武曰：吾入围地，前有强敌，后有险难，敌绝我粮道，利我走势，敌鼓噪不进，以观吾能，则如之何？ 武曰：围地之宜，必塞其阙，示无所往，则以军为家，万人同心，三军齐力，并炊数日，无见火烟，故为毁乱寡弱之形。 敌人见我，备之必轻，则告励士卒，令其奋怒，陈伏良卒，左右险阻，击鼓而出。 敌人若当，疾击务突，我则前斗后拓，左右掎角也。 又曰：敌在吾围，伏而深谋，示我以利，萦我以旗，纷纭若乱，不知所之，奈何？ 武曰：千人操旌，分塞要道，轻兵进挑，陈而勿搏，交而勿去，此败谋之法。 张预曰：前狭后险之地，一人守之，千人莫向，则以奇伏胜。 疾战则存，不疾战则亡者，为死地。 曹操曰：前有高山，后有大水，进则不得，退则有碍。 李筌曰：阻山背水食尽，利速不利缓也。 杜牧曰：卫公李靖曰：或有进军行师，不因乡导，陷於危败，为敌所制。 左谷右山，束马悬车之径； 前穷后绝，雁行鱼贯之岩。 兵陈未整，而强敌忽临，进无所凭#2，退无所固，求战不得，自守莫安。 驻则日月稽留，动则首尾受敌。 野无水草，军乏资粮，马困人疲，智穷力极。 一人守隘，万夫莫向。 如彼要害，敌先据之，如此之利，我已失守，纵有骁兵利器，亦何以施其用乎？
chunks.translated_text:
Du You says: Difficult to return. *Bei* (背) means "to leave"; *bei* is interchangeable with *bei* (倍). *Many* refers to distance. Far from one’s own cities and fortresses, deeply penetrating enemy territory, with single-minded resolve—this is called *heavy terrain*.

Mei Yaochen says: Advancing through a gap, the deeper one penetrates, the more cities one passes. With river crossings and strategic passes cut off, this is called *heavy and difficult terrain*.

Wang Xi says: When troops reach this point, the situation is grave.

He [Shi] says: In *heavy terrain*, having entered deep into enemy territory, provisions from the homeland are hard to supply. If the officers and soldiers do not plunder, what will they take? King Helü of Wu asked Sun Wu: “If I lead my troops deep into *heavy terrain*, crossing many obstacles, with supply lines severed, and wish to return, the situation makes passage impossible. If I seek provisions from the enemy while keeping my forces intact, what should I do?”

Sun Wu replied: “In *heavy terrain*, when the soldiers are bold and transport routes are blocked, plunder to sustain yourselves. Whatever grain and silk the troops obtain should be offered to their superiors. Those who contribute more will be rewarded, and the soldiers will have no thought of returning. If you wish to withdraw, prepare defenses: dig deep moats and raise high ramparts to signal to the enemy that you intend to stay long. When the enemy suspects the main routes, secretly clear the critical paths. Then send light chariots moving silently, using oxen and horses as bait. If the enemy emerges, sound the drums and pursue them. Conceal your troops and coordinate with them at the appointed time. With internal and external forces responding in unison, their defeat is assured.”

Zhang Yu says: Deeply penetrating enemy territory, passing many enemy cities, with the soldiers’ hearts set and no thought of returning—this is *terrain difficult to retreat from*. As Sima Jingwang said of Zhuge Ke’s armored advance: “His momentum is unstoppable.”

Where one traverses mountains, forests, perilous defiles, or marshes—any terrain difficult to traverse—this is called *ruined terrain*.

Cao Cao says: Lacking solidity.

Jia Lin says: *Ruined* refers to land destroyed by water. In marshy, ruined terrain, one cannot stay long and should depart swiftly.

Mei Yaochen says: Land ruined by water is already difficult to traverse—how much more so for battle or defense?

He [Shi] says: *Ruined terrain* is land lacking solidity, unsuitable for building fortifications or digging moats. One should leave quickly.

King Helü of Wu asked Sun Wu: “If I enter *ruined terrain*—mountains, rivers, perilous defiles, and difficult paths—marching for a long time, my troops exhausted, with the enemy before me and ambushes behind, their camps to my left and defenses to my right, their elite chariots and swift cavalry blocking my narrow passes—what should I do?”

Sun Wu replied: “First send light chariots ten *li* ahead to scout and engage the enemy at the perilous points. Some may turn left, others right. The commander surveys the four directions, chooses gaps to exploit, and converges on the main route, halting only when weary.”

Zhang Yu says: In perilous, marshy terrain, advancing and retreating are both difficult, with no place to rely on.

Where the route of entry is narrow and the path of return circuitous, and the enemy can use a small force to strike our larger one, this is called *encircled terrain*.

Li Quan says: Movement is difficult.

Du Mu says: Entry and exit are arduous, making it easy to set ambushes and achieve victory.

Du You says: The route of entry is treacherous, and the return path is distant. If delayed, provisions will run out. Thus, where the enemy can use a small force to strike our larger one, this is *encircled terrain*.

Mei Yaochen says: Surrounded by mountains and rivers, entry is narrow, and return is circuitous.

He [Shi] says: In *encircled terrain*, entry is through narrow defiles, and return is roundabout. With no freedom to advance or retreat, what use is a large force? Only through ingenious maneuvers can one traverse such terrain.

King Helü of Wu asked Sun Wu: “If I enter *encircled terrain*, with a strong enemy ahead and perilous obstacles behind, the enemy cutting off my supply lines and favoring my retreat, their drums sounding but their troops not advancing to test my resolve—what should I do?”

Sun Wu replied: “In *encircled terrain*, one must block the gaps to show there is nowhere to go. Treat the army as your home, uniting ten thousand hearts as one. The three armies should cook together for several days without showing smoke. Appear disorganized and weak. When the enemy sees this, they will surely underestimate your preparations. Then rally the officers and soldiers, rouse their fury, and array your best troops in ambush on the left and right. Sound the drums and charge. If the enemy resists, strike fiercely and break through. Advance to fight while the rear expands, and the flanks support from the sides.

“If the enemy is within our encirclement, lying in ambush with deep plans, luring us with advantages and entangling us with flags, appearing chaotic and directionless—what then?”

Sun Wu replied: “Have a thousand men hold banners, blocking the key routes. Send light troops to provoke the enemy, forming ranks but not engaging, clashing but not retreating. This is the method to defeat their schemes.”

Zhang Yu says: In terrain narrow ahead and perilous behind, where one man can hold off a thousand, victory comes through ambushes and surprise. Swift battle ensures survival; failure to fight swiftly leads to destruction—this is *deadly terrain*.

Cao Cao says: Ahead lie high mountains, behind great waters. Advance is impossible, and retreat is obstructed.

Li Quan says: Blocked by mountains, backed by water, with provisions exhausted—swift action is advantageous, delay is not.

Du Mu says: As Duke Wei Li Jing said: “Some armies, advancing without local guides, fall into peril and defeat, controlled by the enemy. To the left, valleys; to the right, mountains—paths so narrow that horses must be led and chariots suspended. Ahead, impassable; behind, cut off—cliffs where troops must march in single file like geese or fish. Before the battle lines are set, a strong enemy suddenly appears. There is no ground to advance upon, no position to retreat to. Seeking battle is impossible, and self-defense is untenable. If halted, time drags on; if moving, front and rear are vulnerable. The wilds lack water and grass, the army lacks supplies, horses are exhausted, and men are weary. Wisdom is exhausted, and strength is spent. One man guarding the pass can hold off ten thousand. If the enemy seizes such a critical point first, even with elite troops and sharp weapons, what use can they be?”
chunks.overlap_context:
secured their support.

Where one penetrates deeply into enemy territory, leaving many cities and towns behind, it is called *heavy terrain*.
Cao Cao says: Land from which return is difficult.
Li Quan says: Terrain requiring unwavering resolve. Bai Qi’s campaign against Chu and Yue Yi’s conquest of Qi were both *heavy terrain*.
Du Mu says: Having advanced deep into enemy territory and passed many cities, with river crossings and key routes already under their control, retreat becomes impossible.

chunks.original_text: 若此死地，疾战则存，不疾战则亡。 当须上下同心，并气一力，抽肠溅血，一死於前，因败为功，转祸为福。 此乃是也。 陈皞曰：人在死地，如坐漏船，伏烧屋。 贾林曰：左右高山，前后绝涧，外来则易，内出则难，误居此地，速为死战则生； 若待士卒气挫，粮储又无而持久，不死何待？ 梅尧臣曰：前不得进，后不得退，旁不得走，不得不速战也。 何氏曰：死地力战或生，守隅则死。 吴王问孙武曰：吾师出境，军於敌人之地； 敌人大至，围我数重，欲突以出，四塞不通； 欲励士激众，使之投命溃围，则如之何？ 武曰：深沟高垒，示为守备； 安静勿动，以隐吾能； 告令三军，示不得已； 杀牛燔车，以飨吾士； 烧尽粮食，填夷井灶，割发捐冠，绝去生虑，将无余谋，士有死志。 於是砥甲砺刃，并气一力，或攻两旁，震鼓疾噪，敌人亦惧，莫知所当。 锐卒分行，疾攻其后，此是失道而求生。 故曰：困而不谋者穷，穷而不战者亡。 吴王曰：若吾围敌，则如之何？ 武曰：山峻谷险，难以踰越，谓之穷寇。 击之之法：伏卒隐庐，开其去道，示其走路； 求生透出，必无斗意，因而击之，虽众必破。 兵法又曰：若敌人在死地，士卒勇气，欲击之法，顺而勿抗，阴守其利，必开去道，以精骑分塞要路，轻兵进而诱之，陈而勿战，败谋之法也。 张预曰：山川险隘，进退不能，粮绝於中，敌临於外，当此之际，励士决战，而不可缓也。 是故散地则无战 李筌曰：恐走散也。 杜牧曰：已具其上。 贾林曰：地无关闼，卒易散走，居此地者，不可数战。 地形之说，一家之理，若号令严明，士卒爱服，死且不顾，何散之有？ 梅尧臣曰：我兵在国，安土怀生，陈则不坚，斗则不胜，是不可以战也。 王晳曰：决於战则惧散。 张预曰：士卒怀生，不可轻战。 吴王问孙武曰：散地不可战，则必固守不出。 若敌攻我小城，掠吾田野，禁吾樵采，塞吾要道，待吾空虚而来急攻，则如之何？ 武曰：敌人深入，专志轻斗，吾兵安土，陈则不坚，战则不胜； 当集人聚谷，保城备险，轻兵绝其粮道。 彼挑战不得，转输不至，野无所掠，三军困馁，因而诱之，可以有功。 若欲野战，则必因势依险设伏，无险则隐於阴晦，出其不意，袭其懈怠。 轻地则无止，我 李筌曰：恐逃。 杜牧曰：兵法之所谓轻地者，出军行师，始入敌境，未背险要，士卒思还，难进易退，以入为难，故曰轻地也。 当必选精骑，密有所伏，敌人卒至，击之勿疑，若是不至，踰之速去。 杜佑曰：志未坚，不可通敌。 梅尧臣曰：始入敌境，未背险阻，士心不专，无以战为。 勿近名城，勿由通路，以速进为利。 王晳曰：无故不当止也。 张预曰：士卒轻返，不可辄留。 吴王曰：士卒思还，难进易退，未背险阻，三军恐惧，则如之何？ 武曰：军在轻地，士卒未专，以入为务，无以战为。 故无近其名城，无由其通路，设疑佯惑，示若将去。 乃选精骑，衔枚先入，掠其六畜，三军见得，进乃不惧。 分吾良卒，密有所伏，敌人若来，击之勿疑，若其不至，舍之而去。 争地则无攻， 曹操曰：不当攻，当先至为利也。 李筌曰：敌先居地险，不可攻。 杜牧曰：无攻者，言敌人若已先得其地，则不可攻也。
chunks.translated_text:
If in such a death ground, swift battle ensures survival; failure to fight swiftly leads to annihilation. One must unite the ranks in single purpose, combine qi and strength as one, spill guts and splatter blood, resolve to die at the forefront, turning defeat into victory and calamity into fortune. This is the way.

Chen Hao said: “Men in a death ground are like those sitting in a leaking boat or crouching beneath a burning roof.”
Jia Lin said: “With high mountains on both sides and impassable ravines ahead and behind, entry is easy but exit is difficult. If trapped in such a place, only a desperate battle brings life; if one waits until the soldiers’ morale is broken and supplies are exhausted before holding out, what awaits but death?”
Mei Yaochen said: “Unable to advance, retreat, or flee to the side, one has no choice but to fight swiftly.”
He Shi said: “In a death ground, fighting fiercely may bring survival; clinging to a corner means death.”

King Wu of Wu asked Sun Wu: “If my army marches beyond our borders and encamps in enemy territory, and the enemy arrives in great force, surrounding us in multiple layers, with no way to break out—every path blocked—how can I rouse my officers and inspire the ranks to risk their lives and shatter the encirclement?”
Sun Wu replied: “Dig deep moats and raise high ramparts to show preparedness for defense. Remain calm and still to conceal our strength. Proclaim to the three armies that we have no choice. Slaughter oxen and burn chariots to feast the troops. Burn all provisions, fill in wells and hearths, cut hair and discard caps to cast aside thoughts of survival. Let the general have no remaining schemes, and the soldiers embrace the resolve to die. Then sharpen armor and whet blades, unite qi and strength as one. Attack on both flanks, beat drums furiously, and raise a clamor—even the enemy will be alarmed, not knowing where to turn. Dispatch elite troops in separate columns to strike swiftly at their rear. This is seeking life by abandoning the Way.”
Thus it is said: “Besieged yet without strategy, one is doomed; doomed yet without battle, one perishes.”

King Wu asked: “If I am the one besieging the enemy, what then?”
Sun Wu replied: “When mountains are steep and valleys perilous, making escape impossible, they are called desperate bandits. The method to strike them: conceal troops in hidden shelters, open a path for their retreat, and show them an escape route. Desperate to survive, they will have no will to fight. Strike then, and even a large force will be broken.”
The Art of War also states: “If the enemy is in a death ground and their soldiers are fierce, the method to strike them is to yield rather than resist, secretly guard advantageous positions, and open a path for their retreat. Dispatch elite cavalry to block key routes, send light troops to provoke them, array forces but do not engage—this is the way to thwart their plans.”
Zhang Yu said: “When trapped by steep mountains and rivers, unable to advance or retreat, with supplies cut off within and the enemy pressing from without, one must rouse the troops to decisive battle—delay is not an option.”

Thus:
In dispersed ground, do not fight.
Li Quan said: “For fear of scattering.”
Du Mu said: “As explained above.”
Jia Lin said: “With no passes or gates, troops easily scatter. In such terrain, one cannot fight repeatedly. This is one school’s view on terrain. But if commands are strict and clear, and soldiers are devoted and obedient, they would not shrink even from death—how could they scatter?”
Mei Yaochen said: “When our troops are in their homeland, attached to life and land, formations are unstable, and combat is unwinnable—thus one cannot fight.”
Wang Xi said: “If forced to fight, they will fear scattering.”
Zhang Yu said: “With soldiers clinging to life, one cannot lightly engage in battle.”

King Wu asked Sun Wu: “If in dispersed ground one cannot fight, then one must hold fast and not sally forth. But if the enemy attacks our small cities, plunders our fields, blocks our firewood-gathering, and severs our vital roads, waiting until we are weakened before launching a fierce assault, what then?”
Sun Wu replied: “When the enemy has penetrated deeply, their resolve is to fight lightly. Our troops, attached to their homeland, form unstable lines and cannot prevail in battle. We must gather people and store grain, defend cities and fortify strongholds, and send light troops to cut off their supply lines. If they challenge us to battle and find no response, and their provisions fail to arrive, with nothing to plunder in the wilds, their three armies will be starved and exhausted. Then we can lure them into a trap and achieve success. If we wish to fight in the open, we must seize the opportunity, rely on natural barriers to set ambushes, or, lacking such advantages, conceal ourselves in darkness to strike unexpectedly at their moment of slackness.”

In light ground, do not halt.
Li Quan said: “For fear of flight.”
Du Mu said: “The so-called light ground in the Art of War refers to when an army first enters enemy territory, not yet having passed through perilous terrain. Soldiers long to return, finding advance difficult and retreat easy. As entering is hard, it is called light ground. One must select elite cavalry and set hidden ambushes. If the enemy suddenly arrives, strike without hesitation; if they do not come, cross swiftly and depart.”
Du You said: “With resolve not yet firm, one cannot engage the enemy.”
Mei Yaochen said: “When first entering enemy territory, not yet having passed through perilous terrain, soldiers’ hearts are not steadfast—there is no reason to fight. Do not approach famous cities or take main roads; swift advance is advantageous.”
Wang Xi said: “There is no reason to halt without cause.”
Zhang Yu said: “With soldiers eager to return, one cannot linger.”

King Wu asked: “If soldiers long to return, advance is difficult and retreat easy, and the army is not yet past perilous terrain, with the three armies fearful, what then?”
Sun Wu replied: “When the army is in light ground and soldiers are not yet steadfast, the priority is to advance, not to fight. Thus, do not approach famous cities or take main roads. Feign confusion and deception, as if preparing to withdraw. Then select elite cavalry, have them hold bits in their mouths to silence them, and lead the way in. Seize their livestock, and when the three armies see the gains, their fear will turn to eagerness. Divide our finest troops to set hidden ambushes. If the enemy comes, strike without hesitation; if they do not, abandon the position and depart.”

In contested ground, do not attack.
Cao Cao said: “Do not attack; the advantage lies in arriving first.”
Li Quan said: “If the enemy has already occupied perilous terrain, do not attack.”
Du Mu said: “Do not attack means that if the enemy has already seized the ground, one must not attack.”

Wisdom is exhausted, and strength is spent. One man guarding the pass can hold off ten thousand. If the enemy seizes such a critical point first, even with elite troops and sharp weapons, what use can they be?”

chunks.original_text: 梅尧臣曰：形胜之地，先据乎利； 敌若已得其处，则不可攻。 张预曰：不当攻而争之，当后发先至也。 吴王曰：敌若先至#3，据要保利，简兵练卒，或出或守，以备我奇，则如之何？ 武曰：争地之法，让之者得，求之者失。 敌得其处，慎勿攻之，引而佯走，建旗呜鼓，趣其所爱，焚柴扬尘，惑其耳目； 分吾良卒，密有所伏，敌必出救。 人欲我与，人弃我取，此争先之道也。 若我先至，而敌用此术，则选吾锐卒，固守其所，轻兵追之，分伏险阻，敌人还斗，伏兵旁起，此全胜之道也。 交地则无绝， 曹操曰：相及属也。
chunks.translated_text:
Mei Yaochen said: “In terrain of strategic advantage, the first to occupy gains the benefit; if the enemy has already seized the position, do not attack.” Zhang Yu said: “One should not contend by attacking; rather, act later but arrive first.” The King of Wu asked: “If the enemy arrives first, occupies key positions to secure advantage, selects and trains troops, and alternates between offense and defense to prepare for our surprise attacks, what should be done?” Wu replied: “The method for contested ground is this: those who yield gain, while those who seek lose. If the enemy has taken the position, take care not to attack. Instead, feign retreat, raise banners and sound drums, rush toward what they cherish, burn brush and raise dust to confuse their senses. Divide our finest troops to set hidden ambushes, and the enemy will surely come to their aid. When others desire, I yield; when others abandon, I seize—this is the way to contend for the initiative. If we arrive first and the enemy employs this tactic, select our elite troops to firmly hold the position, send light cavalry in pursuit, and set ambushes in perilous terrain. When the enemy turns to fight, ambushes will rise from the flanks—this is the way to complete victory.”

In intersecting ground, do not sever connections.
Cao Cao said: “They are mutually connected and adjacent.”

chunks.original_text: 李筌曰：不可绝间也。 杜牧曰：川广地平，四面交战，须车骑部伍，首尾联属，不可使之断绝，恐敌人因而乘我。 贾林曰：可以交结，不可杜绝，绝之致隙。 杜佑曰：相及属也。 俱可进退，不可以兵绝之。 梅尧臣曰：道既错通，恐其邀截，当令部伍相及，不可断也。 王晳曰：利粮道也。 交相往来之地，亦谓之通地。 居高阳以待敌，宜无绝粮道。 张预曰：往来交通，不可以兵阻绝其路，当以奇伏胜也。 吴王曰：交地吾将绝敌，使不得来。 必令吾边城修其守备，深绝通道，固其隘塞。 若不先图之，敌人已备，彼可得而来，吾不得而往，众寡又均，则如之何？ 武曰：既我不可以往，彼可以来，则分卒匿之，守而易怠，示其不能，敌人且至，设伏阿庐，出其不意。 衢地则合交， 曹操曰：结诸侯也。 李筌曰：结行也。 杜牧曰：诸侯，即上文云旁国也。 孟氏曰：得交则安，失交则危也。 梅尧臣曰：地虽四通，何以得天下之助，当以重币合。 王晳曰：四通之境，非交援不强。 张预曰：四通之地，先交结旁国也。 吴王曰：衢地贵先。 若吾道远而发后，虽驰车骤马，至不得先，则如之何？ 武曰：诸侯参属，其道四通，我与敌相当，而旁有他国。 所谓先者，必重币轻使，约和旁国，交亲结恩，兵虽后至，众已属矣。 简兵练卒，阻利而处，我有众助，彼失其党，诸国掎角，敌人莫当。 重地则掠， 曹操曰：畜积粮食也。 李筌曰：深入敌境，不可非义失人心也。 汉高祖入秦，无犯妇女，无取宝货，得人心如此。 筌以掠字为无掠字。 杜牧曰：言居於重地，进未有利，退复不得，则须运粮为持久之计，以伺敌也。 孟氏曰：因粮於敌也。 梅尧臣曰:去国既远，多背城邑，粮道必绝，则掠畜积以继食。 王晳曰：深入敌境，则掠其饶野以丰储也。 难地，食少则危。 张预曰：深入敌境，馈饷不继，当励士掠食，以备其乏也。 吴王曰：重地多逾城邑，粮道绝塞，设欲归还，势不可过，则如之何？ 武曰：凡居重地，士卒轻勇，转输不通，则掠以继食，下得粟帛，皆贡於上，多者有赏。 若欲还出，深沟高垒，示敌且久，敌疑通途，私除要害，乃令轻车衔枚而行，扬其尘，埃，饵以牛马。 敌人若出，呜鼓随之，阴伏吾士，与之中期，内外相应，其败可知。 圮地则行， 曹操曰：无稽留也。 李筌曰：不可为沟隍，宜急去之。 梅尧臣曰：既毁圮不可依止，则当速行，勿稽留也。 王晳曰：合聚军众，圮无合止。 张预曰：难行之地，不可稽留也。 吴王曰：山川险阻，难从之道，行久卒劳。 敌在吾前，而伏吾后； 营在吾左，而守吾右； 良车骁骑，要吾隘道，则如之何？ 武曰：先进轻车，去军十里，与敌相候，接期险阻。 或分而左，或分而右，大将四观，择空而取，皆会中道，倦而乃止。 围地则谋， 曹操曰：发奇谋也。 李筌曰：智者不困。 杜牧曰：难阻之地，与敌相持，须用奇险诡谲之计。 杜佑曰：居此当权谋诈谲，可以免难。 梅尧臣曰：前有隘，后有险，归道又迂，则发谋虑以取胜。 张预曰：难以力胜，易以谋取也。 吴王曰：前有强敌，后有险难，敌绝我粮道，利我走势，彼鼓噪不进，以观吾能，则如之何？ 武曰：围地必塞其阙，示无所往，则以军为家，万人同心，三军齐力，并炊数日，无见火烟，故为毁乱寡弱之形。
chunks.translated_text:
Li Quan said: “One must not sever connections.”
Du Mu said: “In broad rivers and level terrain, where battles rage on all sides, chariots and cavalry must maintain formation, linking head to tail without break, lest the enemy exploit the gap.”
Jia Lin said: “One may forge alliances, but never cut them off—severance breeds enmity.”
Du You said: “They are mutually connected and adjacent. All may advance or retreat; one must not use force to break their bonds.”
Mei Yaochen said: “Where roads crisscross, fear interception; ensure units remain linked, never broken.”
Wang Xi said: “This refers to supply routes. Such intersecting terrain, also called ‘open ground,’ demands occupying high ground to await the enemy—one must not cut off the grain route.”
Zhang Yu said: “Where paths intersect freely, one must not block the enemy’s way with force; instead, secure victory through ambushes.”
King of Wu said: “In intersecting ground, I shall sever the enemy’s approach. First, order border cities to fortify defenses, block thoroughfares, and secure passes. If we fail to plan ahead, the enemy will prepare, allowing them to advance while we cannot, and with forces evenly matched—what then?”
Wu replied: “If we cannot go forth while they may come, divide troops to conceal them. Guard but feign weakness; when the enemy nears, set ambushes in hidden valleys to strike unexpectedly.”

In thoroughfare ground, unite in alliance.
Cao Cao said: “Form alliances with the feudal lords.”
Li Quan said: “Forge connections.”
Du Mu said: “The feudal lords are the neighboring states mentioned above.”
Meng said: “With alliances, safety; without them, peril.”
Mei Yaochen said: “Though the land lies open on all sides, how gain the world’s aid? Offer rich gifts to unite them.”
Wang Xi said: “In a land of four crossings, strength comes only through alliances.”
Zhang Yu said: “In such terrain, first secure ties with neighboring states.”
King of Wu said: “In thoroughfare ground, priority is paramount. If our path is long and we march late, even with swift chariots and galloping horses, we cannot arrive first—what then?”
Wu replied: “Where feudal lords converge and roads extend in all directions, with the enemy and us facing each other while other states lie nearby—what is called ‘priority’ demands heavy gifts and light envoys to negotiate peace with neighboring states, forging bonds of kinship and favor. Though our troops arrive later, the masses will already be ours. Train soldiers, fortify positions with strategic advantage, and with our allies’ support, the enemy loses their faction. With states attacking from all sides, none can withstand us.”

In heavy ground, plunder.
Cao Cao said: “Stockpile grain and provisions.”
Li Quan said: “Deep in enemy territory, one must not act unjustly and lose the people’s hearts. When Emperor Gao of Han entered Qin, he forbade harming women or seizing treasures, thus winning the people’s favor.” Quan took *plunder* to mean *not plundering*.
Du Mu said: “In heavy ground, with no advantage in advancing and no retreat possible, one must transport grain for a prolonged campaign to await the enemy.”
Meng said: “Draw provisions from the enemy.”
Mei Yaochen said: “Far from one’s state, with many cities at one’s back and supply routes severed, plunder to stockpile and sustain food.”
Wang Xi said: “Deep in enemy territory, raid fertile fields to enrich stores. In difficult terrain, scarcity of food brings danger.”
Zhang Yu said: “Deep in enemy lands, with no supply of provisions, rouse the troops to plunder for sustenance to prevent want.”
King of Wu said: “Heavy ground often lies beyond cities, with supply routes cut off. If we seek to return, the path may be impassable—what then?”
Wu replied: “In heavy ground, where soldiers are bold and transport is blocked, plunder to sustain food. Let those below obtain grain and silk, all to be offered to their superiors, with rewards for the abundant. If seeking to withdraw, dig deep moats and raise high ramparts to signal a prolonged stay. The enemy, suspecting open routes, will secretly clear key points. Then order light chariots to march in silence, raising dust and scattering cattle and horses as bait. If the enemy emerges, sound drums to pursue, while hidden troops lie in wait, coordinating inside and out—their defeat is assured.”

In broken ground, march.
Cao Cao said: “Do not linger.”
Li Quan said: “Do not dig trenches; hasten away.”
Mei Yaochen said: “Where the land is ruined and uninhabitable, move swiftly without delay.”
Wang Xi said: “Gather the army; broken ground is no place to halt.”
Zhang Yu said: “In treacherous terrain, do not tarry.”
King of Wu said: “Where mountains and rivers are perilous and paths arduous, prolonged marching exhausts the troops. If the enemy lies ahead and ambushes behind, camps to the left and guards to the right, with elite chariots and swift cavalry blocking narrow passes—what then?”
Wu replied: “First send light chariots ten *li* ahead to scout and await the enemy, timing their arrival at perilous points. Some may turn left, others right; the commander surveys all, choosing gaps to seize, converging midway before resting.”

In encircled ground, devise strategy.
Cao Cao said: “Deploy ingenious plans.”
Li Quan said: “The wise are never trapped.”
Du Mu said: “In treacherous terrain, locked in stalemate with the enemy, employ cunning and deceptive tactics.”
Du You said: “Here, one must rely on crafty schemes to escape peril.”
Mei Yaochen said: “With narrow fronts, perilous rears, and circuitous return routes, devise strategies to prevail.”
Zhang Yu said: “Hard to conquer by force, easy to seize by stratagem.”
King of Wu said: “With a strong enemy ahead and peril behind, the enemy cuts off our supply routes, forcing retreat. They beat drums but do not advance, testing our resolve—what then?”
Wu replied: “In encircled ground, block all gaps to signal no escape, making the army one’s home. With ten thousand united in heart and the three armies in concert, cook for days without showing smoke, feigning disorder and weakness.”

chunks.original_text: 敌人见我，备之必轻，则告励士卒，令其奋怒，陈练良卒，左右险阻，击鼓而出。 敌人若当，疾击务突，则前斗后拓，左右掎角。 死地则战。 曹操曰：死地战也。 李筌曰：殊死战，不求生矣#4。 陈皞曰：陷在死地，则军中人人自战，故曰：置之死地而后生也。 贾林曰：力战或生，守隅则死。 梅尧臣曰：前后左右无所之，示必死，人人自战也。 张预曰：陷在死地，则人自为战。 吴王曰：敌人大至，围我数重，欲突以出，四塞不通； 欲励士激众，使之投命，则如之何？ 武曰：深沟高垒，安静勿动； 告令三军，示不得已； 杀牛燔车，以飨吾士； 烧尽粮食，填夷井灶； 割发捐冠，绝去生虑，砥甲砺刃，并气一力。 或攻两旁，震鼓疾噪，敌人亦惧，莫知所当。 锐卒分行，疾攻其后，此是失道而求生。 故曰：困而不谋者穷，穷而不战者亡。 所谓古之善用兵者，能使敌人前后不相及， 梅尧臣曰：设奇冲掩。 众寡不相恃， 梅尧臣曰：惊挠之也。 贵贱不相救， 梅尧臣曰：散乱也。 上下不相收， 梅尧臣曰：仓惶也。 卒离而不集，兵合而不齐。 李筌曰：设变以疑之，救左则击其右，惶乱不暇计。 杜牧曰：多设变诈以乱敌人。 或冲前掩后，或惊东击西，或立伪形，或张奇势，我则无形以合战，敌则必备而众分。 使其意慑离散，上下惊扰，不能和合，不得齐集，此善用兵也。 孟氏曰：多设疑事，出东见西，攻南引北，使彼狂惑散扰，而集聚不得也。 梅尧臣曰：或已离而不能集，或虽合而不能齐。 王晳曰：将有优劣则然，要在於奇正相生，手足相应也。 张预曰：出其不意，掩其无备，骁兵说卒，碎然突击。 彼救前则后虚，应左则右隙； 使仓惶散乱，不知所御，将吏士卒，不能相赴； 其卒已散而不复聚，其兵虽合而不能一。 合於利而动，不合於利而止。 曹操曰：暴之使离，乱之使不齐，动兵而战。 李筌曰：挠之令见利乃动，不乱则止。 梅尧臣曰：然能使敌若此，当须有利则动，无利则止。 张预曰：彼虽惊扰，亦当有利则动，无利则止。 敢问：敌众整而将来，待之若何？ 曹操曰：或问也。 梅尧臣曰：此设疑以自问。 言敌人甚众，将又严整，我何以待之耶？ 张预曰：前所陈者，须兵众相敌，然后可为。 故或人问武曰：彼兵#5众於我，而又整肃，则以何衍待之也？ 曰：先夺其所爱，则听矣。 曹操曰：夺其所恃之利。 若先据利地，则我所欲必得也。 李筌曰：孙子故立此问者，以此为秘要也。 所爱，谓敌所便爱也，或财帛子女，吾先困辱之，则敌进退皆听也。 杜牧曰：据我便地，略我田野，利其粮道，斯三者，敌人之所爱惜倚恃者也。 若能俱夺之，则敌人虽强，进退胜败，皆须听我也。 陈皞曰：爱者不止所恃利，但敌人所顾之事，皆可夺也。 梅尧臣曰：当先夺其所顾爱，则我志得行，然后使其惊挠散乱，无所不至也。 王晳曰：先据利地，以奇兵绝其粮道，则如我之谋也。 张预曰：武曰：敌所爱者，便地与粮食耳； 我先夺之，则无不从我之计。 兵之情主速，乘人之不及，由不虞之道，攻其所不戒也。 曹操曰：孙子应难以覆陈兵情也。 李筌曰：不虞不戒，破敌之速。 杜牧曰：此统言兵之情状，以乘敌间隙。 由不虞之道，攻其不戒之处，此乃兵之深情，将之至事也。
chunks.translated_text:
When the enemy sees us and prepares lightly, rally and inspire the troops, rouse their fury, array disciplined warriors, flank them with perilous terrain, and charge forth with drumbeats. If the enemy stands firm, strike swiftly and break through—press forward in combat while securing the rear, and flank them from both sides. In death ground, fight.

Cao Cao said: “This is fighting in death ground.”
Li Quan said: “A fight to the death, with no thought of survival.”
Chen Hao said: “Trapped in death ground, every soldier fights for himself. Thus it is said: ‘Place them in death ground, and they will live.’”
Jia Lin said: “Fight with all one’s might, and one may survive; cling to a corner, and one will die.”
Mei Yaochen said: “With no escape before, behind, left, or right, show them they must die, and every man will fight for himself.”
Zhang Yu said: “Trapped in death ground, men fight of their own accord.”

The King of Wu said: “If a vast enemy force surrounds us in multiple layers, and we seek to break out but find all paths blocked, how can we rouse the troops to fight with their lives?”
Wu replied: “Dig deep trenches and raise high ramparts; remain still and do not move. Proclaim to the three armies that there is no choice but to fight. Slaughter oxen and burn wagons to feast the soldiers. Burn all provisions and fill in wells and hearths. Cut your hair and cast aside your cap, abandon all thought of survival, sharpen armor and blades, and unite in spirit and strength. Attack on both flanks, beat drums furiously, and raise a clamor—let the enemy tremble, unsure where to turn. Dispatch elite troops in separate columns to strike swiftly at their rear. This is how one loses the Way yet seeks life.”

Thus it is said: “Besieged and without strategy, one is doomed; doomed and unwilling to fight, one perishes.” The ancients skilled in warfare could ensure the enemy’s front and rear could not support each other.

Mei Yaochen said: “Through sudden assaults and ambushes.”
Their many and few could not rely on one another.

Mei Yaochen said: “Through shock and disruption.”
Their noble and base could not rescue each other.

Mei Yaochen said: “Through scattering and chaos.”
Their superiors and subordinates could not regroup.

Mei Yaochen said: “Through panic and haste.”
Soldiers scattered and could not reassemble; troops gathered but could not unite.

Li Quan said: “Deploy deceptions to confuse them—strike their right when they rush to save their left, leaving them too flustered to plan.”
Du Mu said: “Employ manifold deceptions to throw the enemy into disarray. Charge their front while ambushing their rear, feign an attack to the east while striking west, create false formations, and display unexpected maneuvers. We engage without fixed form, while the enemy must prepare on all sides, their forces divided.”
Meng Shi said: “Create numerous distractions—appear in the east while striking the west, attack the south to draw them north, leaving them bewildered and scattered, unable to concentrate.”
Mei Yaochen said: “Some may scatter and fail to regroup; others may gather but fail to unite.”
Wang Xi said: “This arises from the disparity between commanders. The key lies in the interplay of the orthodox and the unexpected, like limbs responding in unison.”
Zhang Yu said: “Strike where they least expect, exploit their unpreparedness, and charge with elite troops in a sudden, shattering assault. When they rush to save their front, their rear is exposed; when they respond to the left, their right is vulnerable. Leave them flustered and disordered, unsure where to defend. Officers and soldiers cannot reinforce one another; their troops scatter and cannot reassemble, or gather but cannot unite.”

Act when it is advantageous; cease when it is not.

Cao Cao said: “Provoke them to scatter, disrupt them to prevent unity, then move to engage.”
Li Quan said: “Agitate them until they see an opening, then act; if they remain unshaken, hold back.”
Mei Yaochen said: “To bring the enemy to such a state, one must act only when advantageous, and cease when it is not.”
Zhang Yu said: “Even if they are startled, act only when advantageous, and cease when it is not.”

May I ask: If the enemy arrives in great numbers and strict order, how should we await them?

Cao Cao said: “This is a hypothetical question.”
Mei Yaochen said: “This is a self-posed query. If the enemy is numerous and well-disciplined, how should we face them?”
Zhang Yu said: “The previous discussions assume forces of comparable size. Thus, someone asks Wu: ‘If the enemy outnumbers us and is well-ordered, how should we confront them?’”

Wu replied: “First seize what they cherish, and they will comply.”
Cao Cao said: “Take away what they rely upon. If we first occupy advantageous ground, we will surely obtain what we desire.”
Li Quan said: “Sunzi posed this question to reveal a secret principle. ‘What they cherish’ refers to what benefits the enemy—whether wealth, women, or children. If we first harass and humiliate them, the enemy’s advance and retreat will be at our command.”
Du Mu said: “Secure our advantageous positions, raid their fields, and cut off their supply routes—these are what the enemy cherishes and depends upon. If we seize them all, even a strong enemy’s movements, victories, and defeats will be subject to our will.”
Chen Hao said: “What they cherish is not limited to what they rely upon; anything the enemy values can be seized.”
Mei Yaochen said: “First take what they hold dear, so our will prevails, then throw them into shock and disarray, leaving them with no recourse.”
Wang Xi said: “First occupy advantageous ground, use unexpected forces to sever their supply lines, and they will follow our plans.”
Zhang Yu said: “What the enemy cherishes is advantageous ground and provisions. If we seize them first, they will follow our designs without exception.”

The essence of warfare lies in speed—exploit the enemy’s unpreparedness, advance by unexpected routes, and strike where they are unguarded.

Cao Cao said: “Sunzi responds to the question by reiterating the nature of warfare.”
Li Quan said: “Strike where they are unprepared and unguarded—this is the swiftness of breaking the enemy.”
Du Mu said: “This summarizes the nature of warfare, seizing the enemy’s vulnerabilities. Advance by unexpected routes and strike where they are unguarded—this is the profound essence of warfare and the supreme task of a commander.”

chunks.original_text: 陈皞曰：此言乘敌人有不及、不虞、不戒之便，则须速进，不可迟疑也。 盖孙子之旨，言用兵贵疾速也。 梅尧臣曰：兵机贵速，当乘人之不备。 乘人之不备者，行不虞之道，攻不戒之所也。 王晳曰：兵上神速，夺爱尤当然也。 何氏曰：如蜀将孟#6达之降魏，魏朝以达领新城太守。 达复连吴固蜀，潜图中国。 谋泄，司马宣王秉政，恐达速发，以书给达以安之。 达得书，犹与不决。 宣王乃潜军进讨，诸将皆言达与二贼交构，宜审察而后动。 宣王曰：达无信义，此其相疑之时也。 当及其未定，往讨之。 乃倍道兼行，八日到其城下。 吴蜀各遣其将向西城安桥木阑塞以救达，宣王分诸将拒之。 初，达与诸葛亮书曰：宛去洛八百里，去吾一千一百里，闻吾举事，当表上天子，比相反覆，一月间也，则吾城已固，诸军足办。 所在深险，司马公必不自来，诸将来，吾无患矣。 及兵到，达又告亮曰：吾举事八日而兵至城下，何其神速也。 上庸城三面阻水，达於城下为木栅以自固。 宣王渡水，破其栅，直造城下，八道攻之。 旬有六日，达甥邓贤、将李辅等开门出降，遂斩达。 李靖征萧铣，集兵於夔州。 铣以时属秋潦，江水泛涨，三峡路陷，必谓靖不能进，遂休兵不设备。 九月，靖乃率师而进，将下峡，诸将皆请停兵待水退。 靖曰：兵贵神速，机不可失。 今兵始集，铣尚未知。 若乘水涨之势，倏忽至城下，所谓疾雷不及掩耳，此兵家上策。 纵彼知我，仓卒征兵，无以应敌，此必成擒也。 遂降萧铣。 卫公兵法曰：兵用上神，战贵其速。 简练士卒，申明号令，晓其目以麾帜，习其耳以鼓金，严赏罚以诫之，重刍豢以养之，浚沟堑以防之，指山川以导之，召才能以任之，述奇正以教之。 如此，则虽敌人有雷电之疾，而我则有所待也。 若兵无先备，则不应卒，卒不应则失於机，失於机则后於事，后於事则不制胜，而军覆矣。 故吕氏春秋云：凡兵者，欲急捷，所以一决取胜，不可久而用之矣。 故曰：兵之情虽主速，乘人之不及。 然敌将多谋，戎卒辑睦，令行禁止，兵利甲坚，气锐而严，力全而劲，岂可速而犯之邪？ 答曰：若此则当巷迹藏声，蓄盈待竭，避其锋势，与其持久，安可犯之哉？ 廉颇之拒白起，守而不战； 宣王之抗武侯，抑而不进是也。 张预曰：复谓或人曰：用兵之理，惟尚神速。 所贵乎速者，乘人之仓卒，使不及为备也。 出兵於不虞之径，以掩其不戒，故敌惊扰散乱，而前后不相及，众寡不相待也。 凡为客之道：深入则专，主人不克； 李筌曰：夫为客，深入则志坚，主人不能御也。 杜牧曰：言大凡为攻伐之道，若深入敌人之境，士卒有必死之志，其心专一，主人不能胜我也。 克者，胜也。 梅尧臣曰：为客者，入人之地深，则士卒专精，主人不能克我。 张预曰：深涉敌境，士卒心专，则为主者不能胜也。 客在重地、主在轻地故耳。 赵广武君谓韩信去国远斗，其锋不可当是也。 掠於饶野，三军足食； 王晳曰：饶野多稼穑。 谨养而勿劳，并气积力； 运兵计谋，为不可测。 曹操曰：养士并气运兵，为不可测度之计。 李筌曰：气盛力积，加之以谋虑，则非敌之可测。 杜牧曰：斯言深入敌人之境，须掠田野，使我足食，然后闭壁养之，勿使劳苦。

Chen Hao said: “This speaks of seizing the enemy’s unpreparedness, unforeseen vulnerabilities, and unguarded moments—one must advance swiftly without hesitation. For Sunzi’s essential teaching is that the use of arms values speed above all.”

Mei Yaochen said: “The mechanism of warfare prizes speed; one must strike where the enemy is unprepared. To strike where they are unprepared is to advance by unexpected routes and attack where they are unguarded.”

Wang Xi said: “In warfare, supreme swiftness is paramount—seizing what the enemy cherishes is only natural.”

He Shi said: “Consider the case of Meng Da, a Shu general who defected to Wei. The Wei court appointed him Governor of Xincheng. Later, Meng Da secretly allied with Wu to reinforce Shu, plotting against the Central States. When his scheme was exposed, Sima Xuanwang, then in power, feared Meng Da would act swiftly. He sent a letter to reassure him, but Meng Da remained indecisive upon receiving it. Xuanwang then advanced his troops in secret. His generals urged caution, saying Meng Da was colluding with two enemies and that they should investigate before acting. Xuanwang replied: ‘Meng Da is treacherous and untrustworthy—this is the moment of his hesitation. We must strike before he regains resolve.’ He doubled the pace of his march and reached Meng Da’s city in eight days. Wu and Shu each dispatched their generals to Xicheng, constructing barricades at Anqiao and Mulanse to relieve Meng Da, but Xuanwang divided his forces to block them. Earlier, Meng Da had written to Zhuge Liang: ‘Wan is eight hundred *li* from Luoyang and one thousand one hundred *li* from me. If they learn of my uprising, they will petition the Son of Heaven, and by the time their orders reverse course, a month will have passed—my city will be fortified, and my troops fully prepared. The terrain is treacherous; Sima will not come himself, and if his generals do, I will have nothing to fear.’ When the army arrived, Meng Da wrote again to Zhuge Liang: ‘I rose in revolt eight days ago, and now their troops are at my gates—how could they be so swift?’ Shangyong City was protected on three sides by water, and Meng Da built wooden palisades at its base to fortify it. Xuanwang crossed the water, breached the palisades, and advanced directly to the city walls, attacking from eight directions. After sixteen days, Meng Da’s nephew Deng Xian and his general Li Fu opened the gates and surrendered, and Meng Da was executed.

When Li Jing campaigned against Xiao Xian, he assembled his troops at Kuizhou. Xiao Xian, believing the autumn floods had swollen the rivers and submerged the paths through the Three Gorges, assumed Li Jing could not advance and thus relaxed his defenses. In the ninth month, Li Jing led his army forward. As they prepared to descend the gorges, his generals urged him to halt and wait for the waters to recede. Li Jing said: ‘Warfare values divine speed; opportunity must not be lost. Our troops have just assembled, and Xiao Xian remains unaware. If we exploit the rising waters to appear suddenly at his gates, it will be like thunder too swift to cover one’s ears—this is the supreme strategy of warfare. Even if he learns of us, he will be unable to muster troops in time, and we will surely capture him.’ Thus, Xiao Xian was subdued.

The *Art of War of Duke Wei* states: ‘In warfare, employ the divine and prize speed. Train and refine your soldiers, clarify commands, instruct their eyes with banners and flags, accustom their ears to drums and bells, enforce strict rewards and punishments to discipline them, provide ample provisions to sustain them, deepen moats and trenches to defend them, point out mountains and rivers to guide them, appoint the capable to lead them, and teach them the interplay of orthodox and unorthodox tactics. Thus, even if the enemy strikes with the swiftness of lightning, we will be prepared. If troops lack prior preparation, they will not respond in time; if they fail to respond, they will miss the opportunity; if they miss the opportunity, they will lag behind events; if they lag, they will fail to secure victory, and the army will be destroyed.’ Thus, the *Lüshi Chunqiu* says: ‘In warfare, one must act swiftly to achieve a decisive victory; it cannot be prolonged.’ Therefore, it is said: ‘The essence of warfare lies in speed, exploiting the enemy’s unpreparedness.’

Yet if the enemy’s commander is cunning, his troops harmonious, his orders obeyed without question, his weapons sharp, his armor sturdy, his *qi* keen and disciplined, and his strength full and vigorous—how can one swiftly engage him? The answer: In such cases, one must conceal one’s tracks and silence one’s movements, accumulate strength while awaiting the enemy’s exhaustion, evade his momentum, and wear him down over time—how could one recklessly attack? This is why Lian Po resisted Bai Qi by holding his ground without fighting, and why Xuanwang opposed Wu Hou by restraining his advance.

Zhang Yu said: “Again, addressing another: The principle of warfare values divine speed. What is prized in speed is seizing the enemy’s moment of panic, leaving him no time to prepare. Advance by unexpected routes to strike where he is unguarded, so that he is thrown into confusion, his forces scattered, his front and rear unable to coordinate, and his many and few unable to support one another.

The way of the invader: When deeply entrenched, his resolve is single-minded, and the defender cannot overcome him.”

Li Quan said: “As an invader, the deeper one penetrates, the firmer one’s resolve, and the defender cannot resist.”

Du Mu said: “Generally, in the way of attack, if one deeply enters enemy territory, the soldiers will be determined to fight to the death, their minds unified, and the defender will be unable to prevail.”

Mei Yaochen said: “As an invader, the deeper one enters enemy land, the more the soldiers concentrate their resolve, and the defender cannot overcome them.”

Zhang Yu said: “When deeply penetrating enemy territory, the soldiers’ minds are single-minded, and the defender cannot prevail. This is because the invader is in a position of grave importance, while the defender is in a position of ease. This is why Zhao’s Guang Wujun told Han Xin: ‘When you fight far from your state, your momentum is irresistible.’”

“Plunder fertile fields so the Three Armies have ample provisions.”

Wang Xi said: “Fertile fields yield abundant crops.”

“Carefully sustain them without exhausting them; consolidate their *qi* and accumulate their strength. Devise strategies that are unfathomable.”

Cao Cao said: “Nurture the soldiers, consolidate their *qi*, and devise strategies that cannot be predicted.”

Li Quan said: “With *qi* abundant and strength accumulated, combined with strategic planning, the enemy will be unable to fathom one’s intentions.”

Du Mu said: “This means that when deeply entering enemy territory, one must plunder the fields to ensure ample provisions, then rest the troops behind fortifications without wearing them out.”

Du Mu said: “This summarizes the nature of warfare, seizing the enemy’s vulnerabilities. Advance by unexpected routes and strike where they are unguarded—this is the profound essence of warfare and the supreme task of a commander.”

chunks.original_text: 气全力盛，一发取胜，动用变化，使敌人不能测我也。 陈皞曰：所处之野，须水草便近，积蓄不乏，谨其来往，善抚士卒。 王翦伐楚，楚人挑战，翦不出。 勤於抚御，并兵一力。 闻士卒投石为戏，知其养勇思战，然后用之，一举遂灭楚。 但深入敌境，未见可胜之利，则须为此计。 梅尧臣曰：掠其富饶，以足军食，息人之力，并兵为不可测之计。 王晳曰：谨养，谓抚循饮食周谨之也。 并锐气，积余力，形藏谋密，使敌不测，俟其有可胜之隙，则进之。 张预曰：兵在重地，须掠粮於富饶之野，以丰吾食； 乃坚壁自守，勤抚士卒，勿任以劳苦。 令气盛而力全，常为不可测度之计。 伺敌可击，则一举而克。 王翦伐荆，常用此术。 投之无所往，死且不北， 李筌曰：能得其力者，投之无往之地。 杜牧曰：投之无所往，谓前后进退，皆无所之，士以此皆求力战，虽死不北也。 梅尧臣曰：置在必战之地，知死而不退走。 张预曰：置之危地，左右前后，皆无所往，则守战至死，而不奔北矣。 死焉不得， 曹操曰：士死安不得也。 杜牧曰：言士必死，安有不得胜之理？ 孟氏曰：士死无不得也。 梅尧臣曰：兵焉得不用命？ 张预曰：士卒死战，安不得志？ 尉缭子曰:一贼仗剑击於市，万人无不避之者，非一人之独勇，万人皆不肖也，必死与必生不侔也。 士人尽力。 曹操曰：在难地心并也。 梅尧臣曰：士安得不竭力以赴战？ 王晳曰：人在死地，岂不尽力？ 何氏曰：兽困犹斗，乌穷则啄，况灵万物者人乎？ 张预曰：同在难地，安得不共竭其力？ 兵士甚陷则不惧， 杜牧曰：陷於危险，势不独死，三军同心，故不惧也。 梅尧臣伺杜牧注。 王晳曰：陷之难地则不惧，不惧则斗志坚也。 张预曰：陷在危亡之地，人持必死之志，岂复畏敌也？ 无所往则固，深入则拘， 曹操曰：拘，缚也。 李筌曰：固，坚也。 杜牧曰：往，走也。 言深入敌境，走无生路，则人心坚固如拘缚者也。 梅尧臣曰：投无所往，则自然心固，入深，则自然志专也。 张预曰：动无所之，人心坚固； 兵在重地，走无所适，则如拘系也。 不得已则斗。 曹操曰：人穷则死战也。 李筌曰：决命。 杜牧曰：不得已者，皆疑陷在死地，必不生； 以死救死，尽不得已也，则人皆悉力而斗也。 梅尧臣、何氏同杜牧注。 张预曰：势不获已，须力斗也。 是故其兵不修而戒，不求而得，不约而亲，不令而信， 曹操曰：不求索其意，自得力也。 李筌曰：投之必死，不令而得其用也。 杜牧曰：此言兵在死地，上下伺志，不待修整而自戒惧，不待收索而自得心，不待约令而自亲信也。 孟氏曰：不求其胜，而胜自得也。 梅尧臣曰：不修而兵自戒，不索而情自得，不约而众自亲，不令而人自信，皆所以陷於危难，故三军同心也。 王晳曰：谓死难之地，人心自然故也。 张预曰：危难之地，人自同力，不修整而自戒慎，不求索而得情意，不约束而亲上，不号令而信命，所谓同舟而济，则胡越何患乎异心也。 禁祥去疑，至死无所之。 曹操曰：禁妖祥之言，去疑惑之计。 一本作至死无所灾。 李筌曰：妖祥之言，疑惑之事而禁之，故无所灾。 杜牧曰：黄石公曰：禁巫祝，不得为史士卜问军之吉凶，恐乱军士之心。
chunks.translated_text:
With *qi* complete and strength abundant, strike once to secure victory. Act with adaptability and transformation, so the enemy cannot fathom my intentions.

Chen Hao said: “The terrain where one encamps must have nearby water and grass, with ample supplies and no shortages. Carefully regulate movements and well tend to the soldiers.”

When Wang Jian campaigned against Chu, the Chu forces challenged him to battle, but he refused to engage. He diligently nurtured and guided his troops, consolidating their strength as one. Hearing that his soldiers tossed stones in play, he knew they had been nurtured in courage and longed for battle—only then did he deploy them, and in a single stroke, he destroyed Chu.

Yet when deeply entering enemy territory without seeing an opportunity for victory, one must employ this strategy.

Mei Yaochen said: “Plunder their fertile lands to ensure ample provisions for the army. Rest the soldiers’ strength and consolidate their forces to devise unfathomable plans.”

Wang Xi said: “‘Carefully sustain’ means to meticulously tend to their food and drink. Consolidate their sharp *qi*, accumulate surplus strength, conceal one’s form, and keep strategies secret, so the enemy cannot predict them. Wait for an exploitable opening, then advance.”

Zhang Yu said: “When the army is in perilous terrain, one must plunder grain from fertile fields to enrich one’s provisions. Then fortify defenses, diligently tend to the soldiers, and not allow them to suffer hardship. Thus, their *qi* will be abundant and strength complete, and one may constantly devise unfathomable strategies. When the enemy presents an opportunity to strike, seize it in a single decisive move. Wang Jian’s campaign against Jing frequently employed this tactic.”

Placed where there is no retreat, they will fight to the death without fleeing.

Li Quan said: “When their strength is secured, place them where there is no escape.”

Du Mu said: “‘Placed where there is no retreat’ means that whether advancing or retreating, there is nowhere to go. Thus, the soldiers will strive to fight with all their might, and even in death, they will not flee.”

Mei Yaochen said: “Set them in a position where they must fight, knowing they will die rather than retreat.”

Zhang Yu said: “Placed in perilous terrain, with no escape in any direction, they will defend and fight to the death rather than flee.”

If death is certain, how can victory not be won?

Cao Cao said: “If the soldiers are resolved to die, how can victory not be assured?”

Du Mu said: “When soldiers are determined to die, how can there be no chance of victory?”

Meng Shi said: “If the soldiers are resolved to die, there is nothing they cannot achieve.”

Mei Yaochen said: “How can the troops fail to obey commands?”

Zhang Yu said: “If the soldiers fight to the death, how can their aims not be realized?”

The *Wei Liaozi* states: “If a lone bandit wields a sword and strikes in the marketplace, ten thousand will flee from him—not because he alone is brave, nor because the ten thousand are all cowardly, but because the resolve to die and the will to live are not equal. Thus, the soldiers will exert all their strength.”

Cao Cao said: “In dire terrain, their hearts unite.”

Mei Yaochen said: “How can the soldiers not exhaust all their strength to join the battle?”

Wang Xi said: “When men are placed in a position of certain death, how can they not give their all?”

He Shi said: “Even beasts, when cornered, will fight, and birds, when desperate, will peck. How much more so for humans, the most intelligent of creatures?”

Zhang Yu said: “When all are in dire straits together, how can they not unite in giving their utmost?”

When soldiers are deeply entrapped, they feel no fear.

Du Mu said: “Trapped in peril, they know they cannot die alone, and the entire army shares one heart—thus, they feel no fear.”

Mei Yaochen echoed Du Mu’s annotation.

Wang Xi said: “Placed in dire terrain, they feel no fear; without fear, their fighting spirit is unyielding.”

Zhang Yu said: “Trapped in a position of imminent destruction, men hold fast to the resolve to die—how could they still fear the enemy?”

With no escape, they stand firm; deeply entrenched, they are constrained.

Cao Cao said: “Constrained, as if bound.”

Li Quan said: “Firm, as in resolute.”

Du Mu said: “‘Escape’ means to flee. When deeply entering enemy territory with no path to survival, the soldiers’ hearts become as steadfast as if bound.”

Mei Yaochen said: “Placed where there is no escape, their hearts naturally stand firm; deeply entrenched, their resolve naturally becomes single-minded.”

Zhang Yu said: “With no direction to flee, their hearts stand firm. When the army is in perilous terrain with nowhere to turn, they are as if bound.”

When there is no alternative, they will fight.

Cao Cao said: “When men are desperate, they will fight to the death.”

Li Quan said: “Resolved to their fate.”

Du Mu said: “‘No alternative’ means they suspect they are trapped in a position of certain death and will not survive. Using death to avert death, utterly without recourse, they will all fight with everything they have.”

Mei Yaochen and He Shi echoed Du Mu’s annotation.

Zhang Yu said: “When circumstances leave no choice, they must fight with all their might.”

Thus, their troops require no discipline to remain vigilant, no demands to yield results, no pacts to foster closeness, no commands to inspire trust.

Cao Cao said: “Without seeking, their intent is naturally fulfilled.”

Li Quan said: “Placed in a position of certain death, they will obey without command.”

Du Mu said: “This means that when the army is in a position of certain death, superiors and subordinates share a single purpose. They do not need to be disciplined to remain vigilant, nor do they need to be gathered to align their hearts. Without pacts or commands, they naturally become close and trustworthy.”

Meng Shi said: “Without seeking victory, victory is naturally attained.”

Mei Yaochen said: “Without discipline, the troops remain vigilant on their own; without seeking, their sentiments are naturally fulfilled; without pacts, the masses naturally become close; without commands, the people naturally trust. All this arises from being placed in peril, so the entire army shares one heart.”

Wang Xi said: “This refers to the natural state of men’s hearts in a position of certain death.”

Zhang Yu said: “In perilous terrain, men naturally unite in strength. Without discipline, they remain vigilant on their own; without seeking, they attain mutual understanding; without restraints, they become close to their superiors; without commands, they trust in their orders. This is what is meant by ‘crossing a river in the same boat—how could the Hu and Yue fear discord?’”

Banish omens and dispel doubts, so that even unto death, there is nowhere to turn.

Cao Cao said: “Banish talk of inauspicious omens and dispel doubtful strategies.” (An alternate version reads: “Even unto death, there is no disaster.”)

Li Quan said: “Banish talk of omens and doubtful matters, so there will be no disaster.”

Du Mu said: “The *Huangshi Gong* states: ‘Banish shamans and diviners; do not allow scribes or soldiers to inquire about the army’s fortunes, lest they disturb the soldiers’ hearts.’”
